title: My Weird Winter Experiment: The Pear Tallow Balm That Actually Worked
body:
Okay so I was scrolling Etsy one night. Late. Like 1 AM late. My hands were so dry they looked like old paper. The kind that cracks if you bend it. I’d tried everything. The fancy lotion from the department store. The drugstore tub. The “natural” stuff that smelled like a pine tree. Nothing stuck. My skin just drank it and asked for more. Then I saw this thing. Whipped tallow balm. Pear scent. Made in France. I stared at it. Beef fat. For your face. And hands. I mean. Come on.

My first thought was literally “ew.” My second thought was, well, my great-grandma probably used something like this. And her skin was probably fine. My third thought was that my knuckles hurt. So I clicked buy. It was like $24. I figured it was either genius or a total joke. I didn’t tell anyone. What was I gonna say? “Hey, I’m putting steak juice on my face now.”

It showed up a week later. A little jar. I opened it in my kitchen. The light was that weird yellow from the overhead bulb. I poked it. The texture was… not what I expected. Not greasy. Fluffy. Like cool butter that’s been whipped for a long time. I smelled it. Pear? Sort of. Not like candy. More like a real pear that’s almost ripe. Light. Fresh. Not sweet-sweet. Just… clean. I put a tiny bit on the back of my hand. Cold at first. Then it just vanished. No film. No sticky. My skin just ate it. Huh.

## How I Started Putting Beef Tallow on My Face

Look. I get it. The whole thing sounds insane. Beef tallow skincare? Really? We spent decades running from animal fats. Now I’m buying a jar of whipped cow fat online. From France. It feels like a prank. But here’s the thing I read after I bought it—because of course I googled “is tallow good for skin” after I already spent the money—our skin’s natural oil? Sebum? It’s pretty similar to tallow. Like, structurally. So the idea is it doesn’t just sit on top. It recognizes it. Gets absorbed. Does the job. It’s not a foreign substance. It’s a… familiar one. That was the logic anyway.

My first real test was my elbows. They were a disaster. Rough. Ashy. I’d scratch them on my desk by accident. So one night, after a shower, I just went for it. Scooped a little of this pear tallow balm. Rubbed it in. It melted. Like, instantly. Went from a balm to almost nothing. My skin felt… calm. Not greasy. Not shiny. Just normal. But softer. I went to bed. Forgot about it.

The next morning I was making coffee. Reached for a mug. Brushed my arm against the counter. And I noticed. My elbow didn’t feel like sandpaper. It was just… my elbow. Smooth. Weird. I showed my partner. “Feel this.” He did. “It’s just an elbow.” Exactly. That was the point. It was *just an elbow*. Not a problem. Not a thing I had to fix. Just skin. That’s when I got it.

## What This Pear Tallow Balm Actually Does

It doesn’t do a song and dance. It’s not magic. It just… works. The whipped beef tallow balm thing. It’s grass-fed, they say. From France. I don’t know much about that. But I know my winter skin. It gets angry. Red patches. Flakes. The cold air just sucks the life out of it. This stuff acts like a barrier. But a smart one. Not like putting plastic wrap on. More like giving your skin what it’s missing so it can fix itself.

I started using it on my cheeks. I get these dry spots when the heater’s on all day. Two days. Gone. Not covered up. Gone. I used it on a paper cut. Healed faster. I’m not a scientist. I’m just a person with a jar of weird cream. But the benefits of tallow balm, for me, were stupidly simple. It hydrated without being gross. It fixed problems without a ten-step routine. I’d put it on before bed. Wake up and my face didn’t feel tight. It just felt like my face.

The pear scent is gentle. It’s there when you open the jar. Then it’s gone. It doesn’t follow you around. It’s not a perfume. It’s just a nice thing when you’re putting it on. Sophisticated? I don’t know about that. It’s just a fresh, light, fruity smell that doesn’t scream. It whispers. And then it shuts up and lets the tallow do its job.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

So it’s been maybe a month. Maybe six weeks. I lost track. I think it was a Tuesday when I started. Or a Thursday. Whatever. The point is I stopped thinking about my skin. That’s the real result. I don’t have a before-and-after photo. I just have a life where my hands don’t hurt when I make a fist. Where my face doesn’t feel like a mask. My skin is just… quiet. It’s not perfect. I still get a pimple. I still have lines. But it’s healthy. It’s not freaking out.

I remember reading tallow was good for eczema and psoriasis. I don’t have that. But I had winter damage. My legs looked like a cracked desert. I used this on them after shaving. Big mistake? Nope. No bumps. No irritation. Just soft. It’s like it mimics the skin sebum so well that it just gets along with everything. No fighting.

I told my sister about it. She laughed. Then she tried it when she visited. She took a photo of the jar. “For my eczema,” she said. She ordered one the next week. Now we’re both people who put beef fat on our faces. It’s a weird club. But our skin is happy.

## Would I Buy This Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. I’m on my second jar. I got it from the same little Etsy shop. The one with the French grass-fed tallow. I’ll probably get a third when this one runs low. It sits on my nightstand now. Next to my water glass and a pile of receipts. It’s just part of the routine. Not a weird experiment anymore. Just my cream.

It’s not cheap. But the jar lasts forever. You need the tiniest amount. A pea-size for your whole face. So the $24 doesn’t feel bad. Compared to the $50 serum that did nothing? It’s a steal. I’d buy it again because it’s the only thing that made the dry, itchy, winter skin feeling just… stop. It fixed the problem instead of putting a pretty bandage on it.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult. If the cold air is winning. If you’re curious about this whole beef tallow skincare thing… might be worth a shot. Get past the “ew” factor. It’s just fat. Good fat. Our bodies know what to do with it. Mine did.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. From what I understand, it’s really similar to the oils our skin makes naturally. So it gets absorbed deep instead of sitting on top. It doesn’t clog me up. It just makes my skin chill out and hydrate itself.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not for me. And I can get clogged pores easy. This stuff melts right in. It’s non-comedogenic, which is a fancy way of saying it shouldn’t block pores. My experience says it doesn’t. It just sinks in and disappears.

**What does the pear tallow balm smell like?**
Like a real pear, not candy. It’s light and fresh. You smell it when you open the jar, but it doesn’t stick around on your skin. It’s just a nice, gentle, fruity scent that’s gone in a minute. Very subtle. Very not-overpowering.

So yeah. That’s my tallow story. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. I don’t know what else to say. It just works.
